recipes.strInstructions:
1. Boil pork ears and snout until tender.
2. Grill until crispy.
3. Chop into small pieces.
4. Sauté onions and chili peppers.
5. Add chopped pork, calamansi, and seasonings.
6. Serve on sizzling plate with egg on top.

1. Combine meat, soy sauce, vinegar, crushed garlic, bay leaf, and peppercorns. Marinate for 30 minutes.
2. Transfer to a pot and bring to a boil. Do not stir.
3. Lower the heat and simmer until meat is tender and the sauce is reduced.
4. Serve hot with rice.

1. Boil pork ribs until tender, skimming off impurities.
2. Add tomatoes, onions, and radish.
3. Stir in sinigang tamarind powder mix.
4. Add long beans, eggplant, and kangkong (water spinach).
5. Season with fish sauce and green chili (siling haba).
6. Simmer until vegetables are cooked. Serve hot.

1. Cook thick noodles and set aside.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and annatto in oil. Add shrimp broth, ground pork, and thickened with cornstarch.
3. Pour the sauce over the noodles.
4. Garnish with smoked fish flakes (tinapa), crushed chicharon, boiled shrimp, hard-boiled egg, and green onions.

1. Boil water with fish sauce and tomatoes.
2. Add squash and eggplant. Cook until half-tender.
3. Add okra, long beans, and other greens like malunggay or saluyot.
4. Simmer until all vegetables are cooked. Serve as a simple vegetable stew, usually with fried or grilled fish.

1. Boil beef or pork until tender, skimming off impurities.
2. Add peppercorns and onion to the broth.
3. Add potatoes and cook until half-done.
4. Add cabbage and bok choy (pechay). Cook until tender.
5. Season with salt. Serve hot as a simple, clear soup.

1. Boil whole pork leg (pata) with spices (bay leaf, peppercorn, salt) until very tender.
2. Drain the pata and let it air dry completely for several hours (or overnight in the fridge).
3. Deep fry the dried pata in hot oil until the skin is golden brown and extremely crispy.
4. Chop into serving pieces and serve with a vinegar-soy dipping sauce.

1. Boil pork belly until tender, skimming off impurities.
2. Rub the pork skin generously with salt and pepper. Air dry completely.
3. Deep fry the pork belly in hot oil until the skin is crispy and blistered.
4. Chop into cubes and serve with a dipping sauce like Mang Tomas or a vinegar-soy mix.

1. Clean a whole fish (e.g., Tilapia or Lapu-Lapu).
2. Stuff the cavity with sliced tomatoes, onions, ginger, and lemon/calamansi grass.
3. Wrap the stuffed fish tightly in banana leaves or aluminum foil.
4. Grill or bake until cooked through.
5. Serve with soy sauce-calamansi dipping sauce.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger in oil.
2. Add chicken pieces and cook until lightly browned.
3. Pour in coconut milk and water. Bring to a boil.
4. Add squash and green beans. Simmer until the chicken and vegetables are tender.
5. Season with salt/fish sauce and a little sugar to balance the flavor.
6. Serve hot with rice.

1. Clean and split a whole bangus (milkfish). Remove guts and gills.
2. Stuff the belly with a mixture of chopped tomatoes, onions, and ginger.
3. Wrap the fish in aluminum foil or banana leaves.
4. Grill over medium-hot coals until cooked through.
5. Serve hot with soy sauce and calamansi dipping sauce.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and chicken/pork until browned.
2. Add tomato sauce, water, and bay leaf. Simmer until meat is tender.
3. Add potatoes and carrots, cook until half-done.
4. Add bell peppers and green peas. Simmer until vegetables are tender.
5. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Serve hot with rice.

1. Brown cubed beef in oil and set aside.
2. Sauté garlic and onion in the same pot. Add tomato sauce and water.
3. Return the beef, add soy sauce, bay leaves, and peppercorns. Simmer until meat is tender.
4. Add potatoes and cook until half-done.
5. Add carrots and cook until all vegetables are tender.
6. Season with salt. Serve hot with rice.

1. Boil beef until tender, skimming off impurities.
2. Sauté garlic and onion in oil. Add the tender beef and sauté.
3. Add tomatoes, tomato sauce, and beef broth.
4. Add potatoes, saba banana (plantain), and garbanzo beans. Simmer until tender.
5. Add pechay (bok choy) and green beans right before serving.
6. Serve with a dipping sauce of mashed eggplant, vinegar, and garlic.

1. Boil pork belly until tender, skimming off impurities.
2. Add kadyos (pigeon peas) and unripe langka (jackfruit). Simmer until soft.
3. Add batuan (sour fruit) or tamarind mix for sourness.
4. Add long green chilies (siling haba) and season with salt/fish sauce.
5. Simmer until the dish achieves the desired sour and rich flavor. Serve hot.

1. Marinate chicken breast/thighs in soy sauce, calamansi juice, and pepper for 30 minutes.
2. Pan-fry the chicken quickly and set aside.
3. Fry onion rings until lightly browned and set aside.
4. Pour the leftover marinade into the pan. Add a little water/broth and simmer.
5. Return the chicken to the sauce and simmer until the chicken is cooked and the sauce is reduced.
6. Garnish with fried onion rings and serve with rice.

1. Arrange sliced fish (e.g., Tilapia, Galunggong) in a pot with sliced ginger, garlic, and onions.
2. Add vinegar, water, salt, and whole peppercorns.
3. Add long green chili (siling haba) and bitter gourd (ampalaya) slices (optional).
4. Bring to a boil, then simmer without stirring until the fish is cooked and the liquid is reduced.
5. Serve hot with rice.

1. Marinate pork ribs with salt, pepper, and garlic powder. Pan-fry until browned.
2. Set aside the ribs. In the same pan, sauté mushrooms.
3. Add flour, then pour in beef/pork broth and cream.
4. Stir until the gravy thickens. Season with soy sauce, pepper, and Worcestershire sauce.
5. Return the ribs to the gravy and simmer for 5-10 minutes. Serve hot with rice.

1. Marinate pork belly in soy sauce, vinegar, garlic, and peppercorns.
2. Brown the pork belly in a pot.
3. Add the marinade, water, brown sugar, fermented black beans (tausi), and banana blossoms.
4. Simmer on low heat until the pork is fork-tender and the sauce is thick and rich.
5. Serve hot with rice.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger. Add shrimp paste (bagoong) and pork belly.
2. Add squash and cook until half-done.
3. Add bitter gourd, okra, eggplant, and long beans. Do not stir.
4. Cover and steam/simmer until the vegetables are cooked but still firm.
5. Season with water/broth and serve hot, often with grilled fish.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger in oil.
2. Add the cleaned tilapia and pour in coconut milk.
3. Add chili peppers (siling labuyo) and season with salt/fish sauce.
4. Bring to a simmer and cook until the fish is done and the sauce has thickened.
5. Optional: add a handful of malunggay (moringa) leaves before serving.

1. Marinate chicken pieces in a mixture of vinegar, calamansi juice, garlic, ginger, pepper, and lemon grass.
2. Grill the chicken over hot coals, basting frequently with an oil-annatto (achuete) mixture.
3. Cook until chicken is tender and has a nice char.
4. Serve with rice, soy sauce, and chili-calamansi dipping sauce.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and beef brisket/cubes until browned.
2. Add soy sauce, star anise, brown sugar, and water.
3. Simmer until the beef is fork-tender and the sauce has reduced to a thick, dark glaze.
4. Serve hot with garlic fried rice (sinangag) and a clear soup (pares soup).

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and various meats (pork, chicken, kikiam, liver) in oil.
2. Add chicken/pork broth and bring to a boil.
3. Add fresh egg noodles (lomi noodles) and simmer until cooked.
4. Thicken the soup with cornstarch slurry and beaten eggs.
5. Season with salt/fish sauce and serve hot, topped with fried garlic, spring onions, and calamansi.

1. Separate the meat from the bone of chicken wings to create a 'lollipop' shape.
2. Marinate the chicken in soy sauce, ginger, garlic, and egg.
3. Coat with a mixture of flour and cornstarch.
4. Deep fry until golden brown and crispy.
5. Serve with sweet and sour sauce or banana ketchup.

1. Prepare crispy pork belly (Lechon Kawali style). Chop into small pieces.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger. Add the pre-cooked Dinuguan (pork blood stew) base.
3. Simmer briefly until heated through.
4. Serve the Dinuguan sauce topped with the freshly chopped crispy pork belly.
5. Serve hot with Puto (steamed rice cake).

1. Prepare a flaky pie crust and line a pie dish.
2. Mix young coconut (buko) strips with condensed milk, coconut milk, cornstarch, and sugar.
3. Pour the mixture into the pie crust. Top with a lattice or solid second crust.
4. Bake until the crust is golden brown and the filling is set.
5. Cool completely before slicing and serving.

1. Deep fry firm tofu (tokwa) until golden brown and crispy. Cut into cubes.
2. Boil pork belly until tender, drain, and chop into cubes.
3. Prepare the dipping sauce: Mix vinegar, soy sauce, sugar, chopped onion, and chili peppers.
4. Combine the fried tofu and boiled pork in a bowl.
5. Pour the prepared dipping sauce over the mixture. Serve as a side dish or appetizer.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ground pork/shrimp in oil.
2. Add chili peppers and shrimp paste (bagoong) and cook briefly.
3. Add chopped wing beans (sigarilyas) or long beans (sitaw).
4. Pour in coconut milk and bring to a simmer.
5. Cook until the vegetables are tender and the sauce is reduced and creamy. Serve hot.

1. Cook the vegetable filling: sauté garlic and onion, add ground pork/shrimp, and various chopped vegetables (cabbage, carrots, green beans). Season with soy sauce/oyster sauce.
2. Prepare the wrapper: Cook a thin crepe from egg and flour.
3. Prepare the sauce: Boil water, brown sugar, soy sauce, and thicken with cornstarch. Add crushed garlic.
4. Assemble: Lay the wrapper flat, place a lettuce leaf, spoon the filling, and fold.
5. Pour the sauce over the roll and sprinkle with ground peanuts.

1. Sauté garlic and onion. Add chicken/pork/shrimp and cook until browned.
2. Add carrots, broccoli, cauliflower, and snow peas. Stir-fry briefly.
3. Pour in chicken broth and soy sauce. Simmer until vegetables are crisp-tender.
4. Thicken the sauce with cornstarch slurry.
5. Season with salt and pepper. Add quail eggs or mushrooms if desired. Serve immediately.

1. Boil stingray (pagi) in vinegar and water until tender. Flake the meat.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger in oil.
3. Add the flaked stingray, sliced malunggay leaves (moringa), and chili peppers.
4. Pour in coconut milk and coconut cream. Bring to a simmer.
5. Cook until the sauce is thick and oily.
6. Season with salt and serve hot.

1. Clean and scale whole Tilapia. Rub with salt inside and out.
2. Score the sides of the fish.
3. Fry the Tilapia in hot oil until golden brown and crispy on both sides.
4. Drain excess oil and serve hot with a side of vinegar and garlic dipping sauce.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and chicken pieces until lightly browned.
2. Add water and simmer until the chicken is tender.
3. Add sliced tomatoes and green beans.
4. Whisk in a mixture of flour and milk/cream to thicken the sauce (sarsa).
5. Season with salt, pepper, and fish sauce. Serve hot.

1. Grill or roast whole eggplant until the skin is charred and the flesh is tender. Peel the skin.
2. Mash the eggplant and set aside.
3. Beat eggs and mix with garlic, onion, salt, and pepper. Optional: Add minced pork/beef.
4. Dip the mashed eggplant in the egg mixture.
5. Fry in a pan until the egg is cooked and golden brown.
6. Serve hot with banana ketchup.

1. Combine pork belly/hocks, vinegar, soy sauce, garlic, peppercorns, and bay leaves in a pot.
2. Add water and bring to a boil. Simmer until the pork is tender.
3. Add brown sugar and let the sauce reduce to a rich, tangy gravy.
4. Optional: Add a few slices of fried banana (saba) before serving.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger in oil.
2. Add the prawns (sugpo) and cook until they turn pink.
3. Pour in coconut milk and coconut cream. Add chili peppers (siling labuyo).
4. Season with salt and fish sauce. Bring to a simmer and cook until the sauce is thick.
5. Serve hot with rice.

1. Split a whole bangus (milkfish) open (butterfly cut) and remove the guts.
2. Marinate the fish overnight in a mixture of vinegar, crushed garlic, salt, and pepper.
3. Pan-fry the marinated fish until golden brown and crispy.
4. Serve hot with garlic fried rice (sinangag) and vinegar dipping sauce (Dasilog: Daing-Sinangag-Itlog).

1. Marinate chicken in pineapple juice and soy sauce for 30 minutes.
2. Sauté garlic and onion. Add the marinated chicken and cook until lightly browned.
3. Add pineapple chunks, milk/cream, and chicken broth.
4. Simmer until the chicken is tender and the sauce is thick and creamy.
5. Season with salt and pepper. Add sliced bell peppers before serving.

1. Slice cleaned squid into rings. Marinate briefly in calamansi juice, salt, and pepper.
2. Prepare the batter: Mix flour, cornstarch, salt, pepper, and a little baking powder with cold water.
3. Dip the squid rings into the batter.
4. Deep fry until golden brown and crispy.
5. Serve immediately with vinegar-garlic dipping sauce or mayonnaise.

1. Boil beef shanks with bone marrow and water for several hours until the meat is very tender.
2. Skim off impurities and season the broth with salt and peppercorns.
3. Add whole peppercorns, corn on the cob, and onion.
4. Add cabbage and bok choy (pechay) right before serving.
5. Serve piping hot with rice.

1. Boil pork lungs and heart until tender, then mince finely.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger in oil. Add the minced meat and cook briefly.
3. Add water/broth and simmer.
4. Add diced carrots, bell peppers, and chili peppers.
5. Pour in vinegar and let it boil without stirring.
6. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Serve hot.

1. Cook chicken adobo (or use leftover adobo). Shred the chicken meat.
2. In a pan, heat a little oil and sauté the shredded chicken until lightly crispy and dry.
3. Add some of the leftover adobo sauce/oil for flavor.
4. Serve hot with garlic fried rice (sinangag) and a fried egg (Adosilog).

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger. Add shrimp and shrimp paste (bagoong) and cook briefly.
2. Add squash and cook until half-done.
3. Add bitter gourd, okra, eggplant, and long beans. Do not stir.
4. Cover and steam/simmer until the vegetables are cooked but still firm.
5. Season with water/broth and serve hot, ensuring all vegetables are cooked through.

1. Marinate tuna belly in soy sauce, calamansi juice, garlic, ginger, and pepper for 30 minutes.
2. Grill over medium-hot coals, brushing occasionally with the marinade.
3. Cook until the tuna is done but still moist.
4. Serve hot with dipping sauce (soy sauce, calamansi, chili) and rice.

1. Soak sliced bitter gourd (ampalaya) in salt water for 30 minutes to reduce bitterness. Rinse and drain.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and tomatoes in oil. Add shrimp/ground pork (optional).
3. Add the bitter gourd slices and stir-fry briefly.
4. Whisk eggs, pour over the vegetables, and scramble lightly until cooked.
5. Season with salt/fish sauce and pepper. Serve hot.

1. Mix ground pork, minced shrimp, water chestnuts, carrots, sesame oil, soy sauce, salt, pepper, and egg.
2. Place a small amount of filling in the center of a siomai (wonton) wrapper. Gather the edges but leave the top open.
3. Steam the siomai for 15-20 minutes until cooked through.
4. Serve hot with a dipping sauce of soy sauce, calamansi, and chili garlic oil.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger in oil.
2. Add chicken pieces and cook until brown.
3. Add rice and stir for a minute.
4. Pour in chicken broth and season with fish sauce. Bring to a boil, then simmer, stirring occasionally, until the rice is thick like porridge.
5. Serve hot, garnished with hard-boiled egg, fried garlic bits, spring onions, and calamansi.

1. Cook spaghetti noodles according to package directions.
2. Sauté garlic and onion. Add ground meat and hotdogs/sausages and cook until brown.
3. Pour in banana ketchup and tomato sauce. Add water or broth.
4. Add sugar and seasoning (salt, pepper). Simmer for 15-20 minutes.
5. Serve the sauce over the noodles, topped with shredded cheddar cheese.

1. Marinate pork with sugar, salt, and pineapple juice.
2. Add red food coloring if desired.
3. Marinate overnight in refrigerator.
4. Pan fry in low heat with a little water.
5. Cook until caramelized and slightly charred.
6. Serve with garlic fried rice and egg (Tosilog).

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and annatto seeds until fragrant.
2. Add oxtail and beef cuts, cook until browned.
3. Pour in beef broth and simmer until meat is tender.
4. Stir in peanut butter and ground toasted rice.
5. Add vegetables (banana blossoms, eggplant, string beans, pechay) and cook until tender-crisp.
6. Serve with shrimp paste (bagoong).

1. Soak dried taro leaves in water and drain. 
2. In a pot, combine coconut cream, coconut milk, ginger, garlic, shrimp paste, and chili. Bring to a boil.
3. Add the taro leaves and pork belly (optional). Do not stir until the leaves are cooked and the coconut cream has reduced.
4. Simmer on low heat until the sauce is thick and oily.
5. Serve hot with rice.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger in oil.
2. Add chicken pieces and cook until lightly browned.
3. Add young tamarind leaves, tamarind broth, and water. Bring to a boil.
4. Add vegetables like green papaya or sayote and cook until tender.
5. Season with salt and fish sauce. Serve hot.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger in oil.
2. Add pork slices and cook until brown.
3. Pour in coconut milk and coconut cream. Bring to a boil.
4. Add shrimp paste and lots of chili peppers. Simmer until the pork is tender and the sauce is thick and oily.
5. Serve hot with rice.

1. Clean the snails (kuhol) thoroughly and trim the ends.
2. Sauté garlic, ginger, and onion in oil.
3. Add the kuhol and mix well.
4. Pour in coconut milk and coconut cream. Add chili peppers.
5. Season with salt and fish sauce. Simmer until the sauce thickens and the snails are cooked.

1. Cook pancit canton noodles according to package directions. Drain and set aside.
2. Sauté garlic and onion.
3. Add chicken, pork, and shrimp, and cook until done.
4. Add vegetables (cabbage, carrots, snow peas) and cook for 2-3 minutes.
5. Pour in chicken broth, soy sauce, and oyster sauce. Bring to a simmer.
6. Toss in the cooked noodles. Mix well until the sauce is absorbed. Serve with calamansi.

1. Combine ground pork, minced carrots, onion, egg, salt, and pepper in a bowl.
2. Place a spoonful of the mixture on a lumpia wrapper and roll tightly.
3. Seal the edge with water.
4. Deep fry until golden brown and crispy.
5. Serve with sweet and sour dipping sauce.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger.
2. Add pork belly and shrimp paste (bagoong) and cook until pork is browned.
3. Add squash and bitter gourd, simmer until slightly tender.
4. Add okra, eggplant, and string beans. Do not stir initially.
5. Cover and steam/simmer until vegetables are cooked but still crisp.
6. Season with water/broth and serve.

1. Slice pork belly into 1-inch thick pieces.
2. Marinate the pork in a mixture of soy sauce, vinegar, crushed garlic, pepper, and sugar for at least 4 hours or overnight.
3. Grill the pork belly over medium heat, brushing with the reserved marinade periodically.
4. Grill until the pork is fully cooked and slightly charred.
5. Serve with a dipping sauce of soy sauce, vinegar, chili, and onion.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and lots of ginger in oil.
2. Add chicken pieces and cook until lightly browned.
3. Pour in water and bring to a boil. Simmer until chicken is tender.
4. Add green papaya or sayote and cook until soft.
5. Stir in malunggay leaves (moringa) and season with fish sauce (patis) to taste. Serve hot.

1. Marinate beef slices in soy sauce, calamansi juice, and pepper for at least 30 minutes.
2. Fry the onion rings until lightly browned and set aside.
3. Pan-fry the marinated beef slices quickly on both sides and set aside.
4. Pour the remaining marinade into the pan and let it simmer.
5. Return the beef to the sauce, add a little water or broth, and simmer until the beef is tender and the sauce has reduced.
6. Garnish with fried onion rings and serve with rice.

1. Deep fry a whole cleaned fish (e.g., Tilapia or Lapu-Lapu) until golden brown and crispy. Set aside.
2. Sauté garlic, ginger, and onion.
3. Add julienned carrots, bell peppers, and stir-fry.
4. In a separate bowl, mix vinegar, sugar, water, soy sauce, and cornstarch for the sauce.
5. Pour the sauce mixture into the pan and cook until thick and glossy.
6. Pour the sauce over the fried fish and serve immediately.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger in a pot.
2. Add the vegetables (e.g., string beans, squash, okra) and stir well.
3. Pour in coconut milk and season with salt and pepper.
4. Simmer until the vegetables are tender and the sauce has thickened slightly.
5. Optional: Add shrimp or pork for extra flavor.

1. Prepare the Molo filling by mixing ground pork/shrimp with egg, seasonings, and minced water chestnuts.
2. Fill Molo wrappers with the mixture and seal.
3. In a pot, boil chicken broth.
4. Add chicken chunks and shrimp, and simmer.
5. Drop the Molo dumplings into the boiling broth and cook until they float.
6. Season with pepper, salt, and garnish with green onion and garlic bits.

1. Marinate pork belly in soy sauce, vinegar, and black pepper.
2. Sauté garlic and onion in oil.
3. Brown the marinated pork.
4. Add the marinade, bay leaf, sugar, and water. Simmer until the pork is tender.
5. Add fried saba bananas (plantains) and cook for a few minutes.
6. Add potatoes or carrots if desired. Serve hot.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and a generous amount of ginger in oil.
2. Add chicken pieces and cook until brown.
3. Add glutinous rice and mix well.
4. Pour in chicken broth and season with fish sauce and saffron/kasubha (for color).
5. Simmer, stirring occasionally, until the rice is cooked and the mixture is thick like porridge.
6. Serve hot, garnished with hard-boiled egg, fried garlic bits, green onions, and calamansi.

1. Clean squid, reserving the ink sac.
2. Marinate squid in vinegar, soy sauce, garlic, bay leaf, and pepper for 15 minutes.
3. Sauté garlic and onion in oil.
4. Add the marinated squid and cook quickly.
5. Add the marinade and the reserved squid ink. Simmer for a few minutes until the sauce thickens and the squid is tender.
6. Do not overcook. Serve immediately.

1. Marinate cubed pork in soy sauce and calamansi juice.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and add the marinated pork. Cook until brown.
3. Add tomato sauce and water. Simmer until the pork is tender.
4. Add potatoes, carrots, and cook until half-done.
5. Add cubed liver, raisins, and garbanzo beans. Simmer until all vegetables are tender.
6. Season with salt and pepper. Add green peas right before serving.

1. Boil pork bones to make a rich broth.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger, then add pork offal (liver, intestines) and shrimp.
3. Add the pork broth and bring to a boil.
4. Add miki noodles and simmer until cooked.
5. Season with patis (fish sauce), salt, and pepper.
6. Serve hot, garnished with chicharon (pork cracklings), hard-boiled egg slices, and spring onions.

1. Place leftover Lechon (roasted pig) pieces in a pot.
2. Add Lechon sauce, vinegar, soy sauce, bay leaves, whole peppercorns, and water.
3. Bring to a boil, then simmer on low heat until the meat is very tender and the sauce has reduced and thickened.
4. Season with sugar to balance the sourness and salt if needed.
5. Serve hot with rice.

1. Clean and boil pork leg (pata) until tender. Drain and set aside the broth.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and star anise.
3. Add the pork leg, soy sauce, oyster sauce, sugar, mushroom, and the reserved broth.
4. Simmer on low heat until the sauce is reduced to a thick glaze and the meat is falling off the bone.
5. Thicken the sauce with cornstarch slurry if necessary. Garnish with pechay or broccoli.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger in oil.
2. Add fresh shrimp and cook until they turn pink.
3. Pour in coconut milk and coconut cream. Add chili peppers.
4. Bring to a simmer and add kalabasa (squash) or string beans (optional).
5. Season with salt and fish sauce. Cook until the sauce is thick and the vegetables are tender.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger in oil.
2. Add cubed pork innards and cook until browned.
3. Pour in vinegar and let it boil without stirring for 2-3 minutes.
4. Add pig's blood, water/broth, bay leaves, and chili peppers.
5. Simmer on low heat, stirring occasionally, until the sauce is thick and dark.
6. Season with salt and pepper. Serve hot with Puto (steamed rice cake).

1. Cook thick noodles (palabok or malabon noodles) according to package directions. Set aside.
2. Prepare the sauce: Sauté garlic, onion, and annatto in oil. Add the shrimp broth and thicken with cornstarch. Season with fish sauce.
3. Assemble: Place noodles on a plate. Pour the sauce over the noodles.
4. Garnish generously with boiled shrimp, smoked fish flakes (tinapa), crushed chicharon, boiled egg slices, and spring onions. Serve with calamansi.

1. Clean crabs (alimango). 
2. Sauté garlic, ginger, and onion in oil.
3. Add the crabs and pour in coconut milk and coconut cream. Add chili peppers.
4. Bring to a simmer, then cover and cook until the crabs are done (shells turn red/orange) and the sauce has reduced and thickened.
5. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Optional: add squash (kalabasa).

1. Boil and chop pork lungs and heart finely.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, ginger, and chili peppers.
3. Add the chopped offal and cook until browned.
4. Pour in vinegar and water, then add shredded carrots and bell peppers.
5. Simmer until the sauce is reduced and thickened. Season with salt and pepper.
6. Serve hot, traditionally with rice.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, ginger, and dried fish (dilis) in oil.
2. Add the dried taro leaves and pour in the coconut cream/milk.
3. Add pork cubes or shrimp (optional) and long green chilies.
4. Bring to a simmer, cover, and cook without stirring until the leaves are tender and the sauce is thick and oily (laing na may gata).

1. Boil beef shanks/marrow bones in water until the meat is very tender and the broth is rich.
2. Add whole peppercorns and onion to the broth.
3. Add potatoes, corn on the cob, and carrots, cooking until tender.
4. Add cabbage and bok choy (pechay) right before serving. Season with salt.

1. Marinate chicken pieces in a mixture of vinegar, calamansi juice, lemongrass, ginger, garlic, and pepper.\n2. Baste the chicken with annatto oil (atsuete oil) while grilling over hot coals until cooked through.\n3. Serve with a dipping sauce of soy sauce, calamansi, and chili, and extra annatto oil over rice.

1. Cut fresh, raw tuna into cubes. Rinse and drain completely.
2. 'Cook' the tuna by mixing it with white vinegar and a small amount of calamansi juice.
3. Add sliced red onions, ginger, and chili peppers.
4. Season generously with salt and pepper. Allow to 'cure' for 15-30 minutes before serving.
5. Optional: add a bit of coconut cream for a richer flavor (Kinilaw na may Gata).

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and a large amount of ginger until fragrant.
2. Add chicken pieces and fish sauce (patis). Cook until the chicken is lightly browned.
3. Pour in water/broth and bring to a boil. Simmer until the chicken is tender.
4. Add chayote (sayote) or green papaya and cook until tender.
5. Stir in malunggay (moringa) leaves or chili leaves and serve hot.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and a large amount of ginger in oil.
2. Add chicken pieces and cook until lightly browned. Season with fish sauce.
3. Add glutinous rice (malagkit) and water/broth. Stir constantly to prevent sticking.
4. Simmer until the rice is fully cooked and the mixture becomes a thick porridge.
5. Garnish with toasted garlic, sliced green onions, and a hard-boiled egg. Serve with calamansi on the side.

1. Marinate beef/goat meat in vinegar, soy sauce, and calamansi juice. Brown in oil.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and add the marinated meat. Pour in tomato sauce and beef broth.
3. Add liver spread and peanut butter for a richer flavor. Simmer until meat is tender.
4. Add potatoes, carrots, and olives. Cook until vegetables are tender.
5. Add bell peppers before serving. Season with salt and pepper.

1. Marinate chicken pieces in pineapple juice, soy sauce, and ginger.
2. Sauté garlic and onion, then add the marinated chicken and brown lightly.
3. Pour in coconut milk/cream and the rest of the marinade.
4. Add pineapple chunks and cook until the chicken is tender and the sauce is thick.
5. Season with salt and pepper. Garnish with green onions.

1. Boil mung beans (monggo) until soft and mushy. Set aside.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and tomatoes.
3. Add pork (usually fried or leftover lechon kawali) or shrimp and shrimp paste (bagoong).
4. Add the boiled mung beans and a little water/broth. Simmer.
5. Stir in bitter gourd leaves (talbos ng ampalaya) or malunggay leaves before serving.

1. Deep fry tofu until golden brown and crispy. Cube and set aside.
2. Boil pork belly/ears until tender, then cut into cubes.
3. Prepare the sauce: whisk together soy sauce, white vinegar, water, red onion, and chili peppers.
4. Combine the pork, tofu, and sauce in a bowl. Serve as a side dish, typically with Arroz Caldo (Recipe 82).

1. Marinate beef sirloin in soy sauce, calamansi juice, and pepper for 30 minutes.
2. Pan-fry the beef quickly and set aside.
3. Fry onion rings until lightly browned and set aside.
4. Pour the leftover marinade into the pan. Add a little water/broth and simmer.
5. Return the beef to the sauce and simmer until the beef is cooked through and the sauce is reduced.
6. Garnish with fried onion rings and serve with rice.

1. Coat fish fillet (e.g., Cream Dory, Tilapia) in a batter and deep fry until crispy. Set aside.
2. Prepare the sauce: Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger.
3. Add pineapple chunks, bell peppers, carrots, water, sugar, and vinegar. Bring to a simmer.
4. Thicken the sauce with a cornstarch slurry. Season with salt.
5. Pour the sweet and sour sauce over the crispy fish fillet and serve hot.

1. Mix ground pork, chopped shrimp, chopped water chestnuts, soy sauce, sesame oil, and seasonings.
2. Place a small amount of the mixture onto a siomai wrapper. Fold the wrapper to form a dumpling.
3. Steam the siomai for 15-20 minutes until fully cooked.
4. Serve hot with a dipping sauce of soy sauce, calamansi, and chili garlic oil.

1. Cook pancit canton noodles according to package directions. Set aside.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and chicken/pork/shrimp in oil.
3. Add sliced cabbage, carrots, snow peas, and baguio beans. Stir-fry until vegetables are tender-crisp.
4. Add soy sauce, oyster sauce, and broth. Bring to a simmer.
5. Toss in the cooked noodles. Mix well until everything is coated and serve with calamansi on the side.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger in oil.
2. Add the shrimp (sugpo) and cook until they turn pink.
3. Pour in coconut milk and a splash of water.
4. Add chili peppers and a few pieces of squash (kalabasa) or malunggay leaves (optional).
5. Simmer until the sauce thickens and the shrimp is fully cooked. Season with fish sauce/salt.

1. Marinate chicken pieces in a mixture of soy sauce, calamansi, garlic powder, and pepper.
2. Dredge the marinated chicken pieces in seasoned flour.
3. Deep fry the chicken in hot oil until golden brown and crispy on the outside, and fully cooked on the inside.
4. Serve hot with banana ketchup or gravy.

1. Mix ground pork, minced carrots, onion, egg, and seasonings (salt, pepper, soy sauce).
2. Lay a lumpia wrapper flat. Place a spoonful of the mixture near one edge.
3. Fold the sides in, then roll tightly into a thin cylinder. Seal the edge with water.
4. Deep fry until golden brown and crispy.
5. Serve with a sweet and sour dipping sauce.

1. Prepare Bagnet (Crispy Pork Belly, similar to Lechon Kawali) and cut into cubes.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and a generous amount of shrimp paste (bagoong) in oil.
3. Add squash and cook until half-done.
4. Add bitter gourd, okra, eggplant, and long beans. Add a little water/broth and cover (do not stir initially).
5. Simmer until the vegetables are cooked. Gently stir, then top with Bagnet cubes and serve hot.

1. In a tall glass/bowl, layer various sweet ingredients: sweet beans, coconut sport (macapuno), saba banana, jackfruit, sweet potato, kaong (sugar palm), and nata de coco.\n2. Fill the glass with shaved ice.\n3. Top the shaved ice with a generous pour of evaporated milk, a scoop of ube ice cream, a slice of leche flan, and toasted pinipig (pounded rice).

1. Deep-fry tofu until golden and crispy. Cube and set aside.
2. In a pan, sauté onion, ginger, and green chilies. Add chopped crispy tofu and seasonings (soy sauce, oyster sauce).
3. Stir in mayonnaise to create a creamy coating.
4. Serve on a sizzling plate, topped with egg (optional) and spring onions.

1. Marinate pork cubes in soy sauce and calamansi/lemon juice.
2. Sauté garlic, onion, and add the marinated pork. Cook until browned.
3. Add tomato sauce, water, and simmer until the pork is half-tender.
4. Add potatoes, carrots, and cook until tender.
5. Stir in garbanzo beans (chickpeas) and sliced hotdogs or raisins (optional). Season with salt/sugar.
6. Serve hot with rice.

1. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger. Add cubed pork innards (intestines, ears) and meat.
2. Add vinegar, water, and bay leaves. Simmer until the pork is tender.
3. Stir in pork blood, stirring constantly to prevent lumps. Simmer for a few minutes.
4. Add long green chilies (siling haba) and season with salt/fish sauce.
5. Serve hot, traditionally with puto (steamed rice cake).

1. Boil water with tomatoes, onion, and radish.
2. Add shrimp and sinigang tamarind powder mix. Bring to a boil.
3. Add long beans (sitaw), eggplant, and okra.
4. Season with fish sauce and green chili (siling haba).
5. Simmer until the shrimp is cooked and the vegetables are tender. Serve hot.

1. Prepare the caramel by melting sugar directly in the llanera (oval tin molds). Let it cool and harden.
2. Whisk together egg yolks, condensed milk, evaporated milk, and vanilla extract.
3. Strain the mixture over the hardened caramel in the llanera.
4. Steam the flan for 30-45 minutes until set. Cool completely before chilling.
5. To serve, invert the llanera onto a plate to release the flan and the caramel sauce.
